p: A mono- or polyclonal antibody-based enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) is utilised to recognise TGEV antigens in cell cultures, intestinal contents and faeces (Lanza et al. 1995; Sestak et al. 1996, 1999a; van Nieuwstadt et al. 1988) or PRCV antigen in nasal swabs or lung homogenates (Lanza et al. 1995); however, the sensitivity of available ELISA tests is generally lower than that of RT-PCR assays. RT-PCR or real-time qPCR is now more commonly used for detection of TGEV and distinguishing TGEV, PRCV, PDCoV and PEDV (Kim et al. 2000, 2001; Masuda et al. 2016; Costantini et al. 2004; Ogawa et al. 2009). PRCV/TGEV distinction is usually performed through PCR assay based on the S gene deletion region in PRCV strains. Multiplex RT-PCR and real-time qPCR have been used for the concurrent identification of major porcine viruses related to diarrhoea including RV, TGEV, PDCoV and PEDV (Masuda et al. 2016; Ogawa et al. 2009). Also, multiplex microarray hybridisation assay was used for quick differential identification of eight CoVs, including TGEV (Chen et al. 2005).
